title: People in composites: September 2025
summary: The Gill Corp., Gurit, Syensqo, Carbitex, GE Aerospace and the University of Southern Queensland have made new appointments or announced upcoming leadership transitions within the composites industry.

summary_detail.value: The Gill Corp., Gurit, Syensqo, Carbitex, GE Aerospace and the University of Southern Queensland have made new appointments or announced upcoming leadership transitions within the composites industry.

content.value:
The Gill Corp. welcomes new COO

Andrew Brandenburg, The Gill Corp. chief operating officer (COO).

The Gill Corp. (El Monte, Calif., U.S.) announce the appointment of Andrew Brandenburg as chief operating officer (COO). With more than 25 years of experience in aerospace manufacturing, Brandenburg brings a wealth of expertise to help drive the El Monte facility’s continued growth.

In his role as COO, Brandenburg will oversee operations, including manufacturing, supply chain and planning, where he will spearhead operational initiatives, and foster high-performance teams. Holding an MBA and a BS in aeronautical engineering, his expertise spans people management, sales growth initiatives, global operations management and continuous improvement, demonstrating a strong blend of engineering and hands-on functional management experience and acquisition diligence.

GE Aerospace names chief mechanic for open fan

GE Aerospace (Cincinnati, Ohio, U.S.) has named Craig Higgins as chief mechanic and architect for Open Fan technology, prioritizing the producibility, durability and maintainability of next-generation engine designs still in development. 

In the newly created role, Higgins will lead strategies for a simple, lightweight engine concept that emphasizes durability by leveraging the CFM RISE program’s advanced technologies, architectures and materials. This includes working with technicians and other experts across GE Aerospace’s global assembly and maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO) shops to incorporate the latest techniques for enabling more on-wing repairs and part replacements.

“With the RISE program, we’re advancing a suite of pioneering technologies to meet our customers’ needs for the future of flight,” says Arjan Hegeman, vice president for future of flight at GE Aerospace. “This marks the first time we’ve named a chief mechanic during technology development, making durability and maintainability a top priority in engine design with an uncompromising commitment to safety.” 

Higgins has more than 40 years’ experience in the aerospace industry, joining GE Aerospace in 1997 as a design engineer. In his most recent role, he was a consulting engineer for the RISE program. 

Unveiled in 2021, the CFM RISE program is a comprehensive technology demonstrators with more than 350 tests and more than 3,000 cycles of endurance tests completed to date, including tests on advanced engine architectures like Open Fan, compact core and hybrid electric systems.  CFM RISE program technologies are maturing toward ground and flight tests this decade with work underway on aircraft and engine integration in collaboration with partners.

Syensqo announces new CEO starting in 2026

Mike Radossich, new Syensqo CEO.

Syensqo’s (Brussels, Belgium and Alpharetta, Ga., U.S.) Mike Radossich will be succeeding Dr. Ilham Kadri as CEO of Syensqo as of Jan. 1 2026. Kadri’s tenure has been transformative, the company says. She successfully completed the separation of Syensqo from Solvay in December 2023, with the two companies now financially sound and publicly listed.

“On behalf of the board and the entire organization, I want to thank Ilham wholeheartedly for her impressive and transformative tenure of Solvay first, and Syensqo later. She has been a defining voice for our two companies and the whole industry,” says Rosemary Thorne, chair of Syensqo’s board of directors. “Ilham is credited with transforming a 160-year-old industrial group, turning Solvay’s returns to double-digit levels. She revolutionized how we do business and her focus has always been on how to generate profitable growth while creating a strong purpose-built culture for our people. Her vision, disciplined approach to capital allocation and relentless energy will leave an indelible legacy on our people, customers and shareholders. We wish her all the best in her next chapter.”

Radossich has a successful track record in transforming complex businesses and delivering growth and operational efficiency at global scale. He has worked at Syensqo and its predecessor companies for more than 30 years. As the current president of Syensqo’s Performance & Care and Other Solutions segments, he is responsible for overseeing four global business units which generated €2.8 billion in net sales in 2024. At Solvay Group, he helped the Novecare Business Unit deliver strong financial results and achieve sustainable and profitable growth. He had joined the group in the context of Solvay’s acquisition of Cytec Industries in 2015.

“I’m happy that Mike will lead the next chapter of Syensqo,” notes Kadri. “Having worked closely with him over the last 6 years, giving him increasingly more responsibilities, I know he is an exceptional leader with the energy and results-oriented approach needed to advance Syensqo’s goals, through the next chapter of our journey.”

Gurit appoints new CFO starting December 2025

Viktor Bernhardt, new CFO of Gurit.

Gurit (Zurich, Switzerland) has appointed Viktor Bernhardt as its new chief financial officer (CFO), effective Dec. 1, 2025. Bernhardt, a German national, will succeed Javier Perez-Freije, who departs by the end of November 2025.  

Bernhardt brings more than 25 years of international finance and leadership experience, having held senior positions across multinational corporations, private equity portfolio companies and family-owned businesses. He has an extensive track record in corporate transformation, restructuring, M&A execution and strategic growth. 

His extensive experience in financial management will be instrumental in guiding the company through its next phase. Gurit is confident that Bernhardt will make significant contributions to its financial strategy and overall success.

Viktor holds a degree in business administration from TA Wuppertal (Germany) and completed executive education at Insead, Fontainebleau (France). Most recently, he served as CFO of the KWC Group.

“On behalf of the board of directors, I want to thank Javier for his dedication and wish him all the best for the future, and welcome Viktor to our executive team and wish him a strong start and much success as he steps into this pivotal role at Gurit,” says Tobias Lührig, CEO of Gurit. 

Carbitex makes strategic hire for flexible carbon fiber acceleration

Carbitex Inc. (Kennewick, Wash., U.S.) announces the appointment of Adrienne Cristofoli as vice president (VP) of marketing. Cristofoli joins the team as the company enters a major growth phase that will see brand partnerships more than double from 2025 to 2026.

Adrienne Cristofoli, Carbitex VP of marketing. 

With the foundation established and demand accelerating, Carbitex is now focused on scaling its impact and elevating the role of flex as the next major frontier in footwear innovation. Cristofoli, based in Portland, Oregon, will lead efforts to define Carbitex’s brand voice, amplify brand partners and drive industry-wide recognition of flex as a critical performance attribute — one that has traditionally been treated as a byproduct of cushioning or stability rather than a performance driver in its own right.

“When we set out to find a marketing leader, we weren’t just looking for the right teammate with the right skill set, we were looking for someone with proven experience in executing unconventional campaigns,” says Junus Khan, president and founder of Carbitex. “Plenty of candidates resonated with our vision, but Adrienne stood out because she has actually brought technical ideas to market in a bold way that made them resonate. That is rare, and it’s exactly what Carbitex needs as we accelerate.”

Most recently, Cristofoli served as brand marketing director at SAXX Underwear, where she transformed patented innovation into simple, relatable stories that drove awareness and cultural relevance. Prior to SAXX, she spent more than a decade shaping billion-dollar brands like Huggies and Häagen-Dazs, as well as guiding challenger brands through high-growth phases.

“The opportunity to elevate the importance of flex in footwear — and to use Carbitex’s technology as the platform to tell that story — is exciting,” says Cristofoli. “I see an opportunity to make Carbitex as bold and distinctive as its innovation, and to establish it as a household name in the footwear space.”

As a former Division 1 track athlete, Cristofoli brings to Carbitex her competitive spirit and first-hand understanding of what athletes look for in performance. Cristofoli will build out marketing strategy and operations, working closely alongside Carbitex’s product development and sales teams as the company moves into the next chapter.

UniSQ iLAuNCH says goodbye to program leaders

Dr. Milica Symul (left) and Darin Lovett (right).

After successfully establishing Australia’s 
iLAuNCH Trailblazer program and overseeing a comprehensive suite of commercialization projects, executive director Darin Lovett and COO Dr. Milica Symul will conclude their time at the University of Southern Queensland (UniSQ) on Oct. 3 following the International Astronautical Congress (IAC).

Lovett and Symul have made many contributions to iLAuNCH, shaping it into a nationally significant research and commercialization program. Under their leadership, iLAuNCH has grown into a thriving program, delivering nine space missions, more than 30 programs and mobilizing more than $200 million in investment with $187 million already contracted into industry projects. Their vision has laid a strong foundation for its future.

Looking ahead, professor Peter Schubel has been appointed acting executive director of the iLAuNCH Trailblazer. Schubel was instrumental in leading the original iLAuNCH bid and brings more than 20 years of aerospace and space R&D experience, including leadership of current iLAuNCH projects.

Dr. Samantha Rose, director of the Office of Research at UniSQ, will step into the role of center manager for iLAuNCH. Rose brings more than a decade of experience in research management and extensive expertise in leading large-scale, multi-partner initiatives.

The university extends its sincere thanks to Lovett and Symul, who shared the following message: “From ‘Mission Impossible’ to ‘Mission Accomplished’ — this has been the spirit of iLAuNCH. Together, we have turned ambition into reality, forging sovereign Australian space capability through relentless determination and true partnership. We are proud of what has been built and deeply grateful to every partner who placed their trust in this vision. Though our time now concludes, we take pride in the legacy of nine space missions, breakthrough products and enduring collaborations that are now firmly established through iLAuNCH. Thank you for the journey. It has been our honor.”

title: Kratos becomes exclusive U.S. manufacturer for Elroy Air Chaparral VTOL cargo drone

title_detail.value: Kratos becomes exclusive U.S. manufacturer for Elroy Air Chaparral VTOL cargo drone

summary: Five-year partnership leverages Kratos’ expertise in scaled infrastructure and delivering affordable, jet-powered composite unmanned aircraft to put the Chaparral into high-volume production.

summary_detail.value: Five-year partnership leverages Kratos’ expertise in scaled infrastructure and delivering affordable, jet-powered composite unmanned aircraft to put the Chaparral into high-volume production.

content.value:
Elroy Air’s Chaparral, shown here in flight, to be manufactured by Kratos. Source | Kratos

Elroy Air (South San Francisco, Calif., U.S.), a developer of autonomous aerial cargo systems for middle-mile logistics and military resupply, has selected Kratos Defense & Security Solutions Inc. (San Diego, Calif., U.S.) as its exclusive U.S. manufacturing partner for the Chaparral. This new 5-year strategic manufacturing agreement is expected to accelerate high-volume production of the hybrid-electric autonomous vertical takeoff and landing (VTOL) cargo drone, which features a full carbon fiber composite airframe.

“Kratos is an established and trusted producer of military UAS and is distinctive in their manufacturing focus on affordability,” explains Elroy Air CEO Andrew Clare. “Kratos has produced and delivered thousands of uncrewed aircraft, with a well-established and reliable supply chain for these systems. Their expanded production capabilities make them the ideal partner to bring Chaparral to market at scale.”

Kratos, known for its development and production of affordable, jet-powered composite unmanned aircraft for the U.S. Department of Defense, recently expanded its manufacturing capacity to support next-gen drone production. 

Chaparral is designed to autonomously transport up to 300 pounds of cargo over 300 miles, affordably bridging critical logistics gaps for military resupply, disaster relief and commercial express delivery. The vehicle’s hybrid-electric powertrain enables rapid refueling, extra power for recharging batteries and powering payloads in cruise flight, and longer-range cargo transport than similar-sized battery-electric aircraft.

Kratos will perform initial production of Chaparral at its Sacramento, California, aircraft production facility and over time, transition to high-rate production at Kratos’ facilities in Oklahoma City. These efforts are expected to bring aerospace jobs to both regions and expand the current supply chain infrastructure that includes many other states across the U.S. The first production Chaparral aircraft are planned to be built in 2026.

title: SGL Carbon and Carbon Cleanup form autocomposite recycling partnership

title_detail.value: SGL Carbon and Carbon Cleanup form autocomposite recycling partnership

summary: An AI-supported collection system, recycling program and CARB-E tech, already demonstrating CO2 part reduction in early automotive applications, are building recycling scalability.

summary_detail.value: An AI-supported collection system, recycling program and CARB-E tech, already demonstrating CO2 part reduction in early automotive applications, are building recycling scalability.

content.value:
Automotive waste. Source | Carbon Cleanup

SGL Carbon (Ried im Innkreis, Ort im Innkreis) and composite recycling company Carbon Cleanup (Traun, Austria) are seeking to improve waste management in automotive manufacturing via Carbon Cleanup’s CARB-E (Carbon Eater) recycling technology, which is both scalable and economically viable.

Carbon fiber scraps from automotive production have long been a challenge for waste management — bulky, difficult to recycle and often destined for landfill or incineration. In a partnership that has grown over the past 3 years, SGL Carbon and Carbon Cleanup are returning these materials to the loop.

Using CARB-E, automotive carbon fiber scraps are processed with a near-zero carbon footprint (0.036 kg CO₂ eq. per kilogram). The recycled fibers are then used as reinforcement in injection molding compounds, giving the material a second life while replacing virgin fibers such as glass fiber. Early applications, including a super sports car front hood, has demonstrated a 30% CO₂ reduction per part compared to the original material used. 

The partnership began as a “Frontrunnership” to test material recyclability and has since scaled significantly. A dedicated logistics system for the recycling program has been developed, and more than 50 tons of carbon fiber scraps have already been recycled in 2025. Volumes are expected to triple by the end of the year, marking a milestone for industrial-scale circularity.

Within the partnership, waste audits, digitalizing waste and iteration loops, a smart AI-supported collection system has also been developed to track waste from the point it is generated all the way to the final product or even second-life part.

“For the final product, it’s key to know exactly where the waste came from. And for material scientists, that data is gold when it comes to creating the right formulations,” says Jakob Schlosser, CTO Carbon Cleanup. “That’s why our system makes sure every piece of waste is tracked, traceable and connected across the recycling network.”

title: Nova Carbon, Grand Large Yachting to integrate rCF into shipbuilding

title_detail.value: Nova Carbon, Grand Large Yachting to integrate rCF into shipbuilding

summary: Strategic partnership aims to reduce the environmental impact of luxury yacht construction by integrating Nova Carbon rCF into the boatbuilder’s manufacturing processes.

summary_detail.value: Strategic partnership aims to reduce the environmental impact of luxury yacht construction by integrating Nova Carbon rCF into the boatbuilder’s manufacturing processes.

content.value:
Outremer 52 yacht. Source (All Images) | Grand Large Yachting, Nova Carbon

Nova Carbon (Mérignac, France), a startup specializing in carbon fiber reclamation, and international shipbuilding group Grand Large Yachting (Normandie, France), have signed a strategic partnership to reduce the environmental footprint of luxury yacht construction through the integration of high-performance recycled carbon fiber (rCF).

Created in 2003, Grand Large Yachting’s mission is to enable everyone, seasoned sailors or not, to fulfill their dream of small- or long-distance sailing journeys with low environmental impact. Grand Large Yachting embodies nautical excellence through six brands: Gunboat, Outremer, ORC, Garcia, Allure and RM.

Aware of the environmental impact of its materials, the Grand Large Yachting team is taking a proactive approach by gradually replacing a portion of virgin carbon fiber with rCF, using the technology developed by Nova Carbon.

Nova Carbon rCF. 

For its part, Nova Carbon develops and produces the Nova Carbon product, a high-performance rCF based on the realignment of fibers collected from industrial partners. The reclaimed material, providing the high technical performance of virgin fiber with a reduced environmental footprint, offers a sustainable and competitive alternative for the marine industry.

As part of this partnership, the two companies have agreed on several key commitments:

  • Circular collection and valorization: Grand Large Yachting will provide Nova Carbon’s carbon fiber waste, following the conditions and recommendations set by the startup, to ensure its recyclability and quality.
  • Integration of recycled fibers: Grand Large Yachting aims to explore and develop solutions to reintegrate the Nova Carbon from its own waste into its manufacturing processes.

The approach is based on a constant pursuit of quality and traceability, through rigorous processes and certified materials.

This initiative could also be gradually extended to Grand Large Yachting’s subcontractors, amplifying its positive impact across the entire industry supply chain. The goal is to increase the use of high-performance rCF in the group’s projects.

title: Dymag reveals Halo X-track-approved wheels for Porsche GT3 RS

title_detail.value: Dymag reveals Halo X-track-approved wheels for Porsche GT3 RS

summary: Exclusive for Porsche, but with additional applications under development, the carbon fiber composite Halo wheel is certified for road-legal track cars.

summary_detail.value: Exclusive for Porsche, but with additional applications under development, the carbon fiber composite Halo wheel is certified for road-legal track cars.

content.value:
Source | Dymag Technologies

Dymag Technologies Ltd. (Wiltshire, U.K.) has announced the launch of the Halo wheel, its first complete carbon fiber composite car wheel designed exclusively for the Porsche (992.1) 911 GT3 RS. Additional applications are in development.

Halo combines a forged aluminum centerpiece with Dymag’s carbon fiber rim technology. Its patented Dymag BX-F flange profile is designed to minimize bead seat damage and maintain tire pressure under extreme impacts, an area where conventional wheels often suffer complete pressure loss. The wheel is engineered entirely in-house to deliver performance on both the road and the track. It is certified under SAE, JWL and most international standards, with TÜV approval in progress.

The front wheel size is 20 × 10 inches, weighs 7.49 kilograms has a 350-kilogram load rating. The Halo rear wheel size is 21 × 13 inches, weighs 9.77 kilograms, with a 615-kilogram load rating.

“Marking our 50th anniversary, this wheel draws on half a century of racing success — from Formula 1, IndyCar and Le Mans through to World Rally and Dakar,” says Christopher Shelley, executive chair of Dymag. Today, Dymag’s BX-F carbon fiber wheel designs are being adopted by major OEMs, as automotive manufacturers increasingly recognize the performance, efficiency and safety benefits of lightweight carbon fiber hybrid wheels.

To coincide with the launch of Halo, Dymag has unveiled a refreshed brand identity and positioning, supported by a new website.

title: HydroGraph graphene, coatings to advance Seadar subsea radar

title_detail.value: HydroGraph graphene, coatings to advance Seadar subsea radar

summary: Technical synergies will be explored to enhance the performance of Seadar’s radars, nodes, tethers and electronics, like graphene-enhanced Kevlar-reinforced survey lines and graphene composite structural components.

summary_detail.value: Technical synergies will be explored to enhance the performance of Seadar’s radars, nodes, tethers and electronics, like graphene-enhanced Kevlar-reinforced survey lines and graphene composite structural components.

content.value:
A 3D schematic illustration of Seadar Technologies’ flagship product, the Seadar Shield, a subsea intruder detection radar system. It visually depicts a typical deployment scenario for maritime security and surveillance, aligning with Seadar’s focus on enhancing port defense and deep-sea resource discovery. Source | Seadar Technologies

Ultra-pure graphene producer HydroGraph Inc. (Vancouver, BC, Canada) and Seadar Technologies (Dallas, Texas, U.S.), developing subsea sensing and surveillance solutions, have signed a letter of intent (LOI) to integrate HydroGraph’s graphene materials and coating technologies into Seadar’s current and future undersea products.

The deal fuses two breakthroughs, graphene and subsea radar, into technologies built for tough marine environments, where corrosion, pressure and salt often destroy marine systems quickly. According to HydroGraph, graphene coatings and composites could make Seadar’s platforms last longer, perform better and cut costs. 

“Graphene is a versatile and durable substance. Partnering with Seadar enables us to develop new applications that can deliver real-world benefits,” says Kjirstin Breure, president and CEO of HydroGraph. 

Both companies plan to explore applications for HydroGraph graphene for various Seadar applications and systems. For example, adding graphene to Kevlar-reinforced survey lines can increase tensile strength, reduce weight and improve handling. Graphene coatings can reduce corrosion and extend the life of Seadar Shield node boxes and connectors. Graphene composites can make Seadar structural components lighter and stronger, enabling them to handle mechanical loads and subsea pressures. Graphene can also improve thermal conductivity, dissipating heat to protect sensitive electronics.

HydroGraph specializes in commercializing graphene production, supporting materials innovation for marine, aerospace and industrial applications. The company has developed a controlled chamber explosion method to produce few-layered graphene at scale, cost-effectively.

title: BladeBridge repurposes Energia Group decommissioned wind blade into practical site amenity

title_detail.value: BladeBridge repurposes Energia Group decommissioned wind blade into practical site amenity

summary: Collaborative effort turns EOL blade into a rest area and memorial along the Meenadreen Wind Farm’s Leghowney Loop trail, blending sustainable design and functionality.

summary_detail.value: Collaborative effort turns EOL blade into a rest area and memorial along the Meenadreen Wind Farm’s Leghowney Loop trail, blending sustainable design and functionality.

content.value:
Source | Energia Group

Energy utility company Energia Renewables (Dublin, Ireland and Belfast, Northern Ireland) has found a new use for a decommissioned turbine blade, which was replaced on the Meenadreen Wind Farm back in 2020. Working with BladeBridge (Cork, Ireland), a startup formed from the U.S. academic project Re-Wind Network, the groups have transformed the end-of-life (EOL) wind blade into a new site amenity in the form of a shelter and seating area on the Leghowney Loop, a popular trail which passes through the wind farm. 

Design companies like BladeBridge are helping to repurpose decommissioned blades and turn them into functional street furniture, bus shelters and even pedestrian bridges. The company works with wind farm operators with redundant blades and public bodies looking for low-carbon options for pedestrian bridges, bus shelters, public benches and other solutions.

The Meenadreen blade is the first time BladeBridge has worked on a wind farm amenity project, where the blade will return to its original home to continue its working life in a new form. Aligned to the UN Sustainability Development Goals, and with sustainability at the core of everything it does, Energia commissioned BladeBridge in an effort to enhance the site for walkers on the Leghowney Loop trail, promote the circular economy and raise public awareness of the possibilities and need to repurpose waste materials through sustainable resource management. 

The completed blade project consists of an eye-catching shelter, stylish picnic table structure with seating and standalone benches. Simon Dennehy from Perch Design, BladeBridge’s creative director, says he believes in the importance of highlighting blade engineering features in any new form. “These blades are amazing, organic, undulating and asymmetric structures and I want to preserve these design aspects so that people will know that they are sitting on, or standing under, something that was once part of a wind turbine, which will now last for many more decades.”

The centerpiece of the walkers’ rest area is the shelter, which is dedicated to one of the engineers who worked on the site, Jimmy Kelly from Carrowbeg in Co. Mayo, who was an Irish wind energy pioneer. 

“Jimmy was a renewable energy expert and enthusiast,” says Brian Mullen, head of Energia Renewables Operations. “He generated his own electricity at home, was an organic farmer and even made his own Mayo wine. An expert in too many fields to list, Jimmy would no doubt accuse us of making a fuss. However, he’d be blown away to see a blade he’d worked on transformed and still in use.”

title: Brunswick Boat Group to consolidate fiberglass boat manufacturing operations

title_detail.value: Brunswick Boat Group to consolidate fiberglass boat manufacturing operations

summary: Brunswick Corp. will close its Reynosa, Mexico, and Flagler Beach, Florida, boat manufacturing facilities, shifting production to high-performing U.S. plants to align with a streamlined product portfolio and evolving market demand.

summary_detail.value: Brunswick Corp. will close its Reynosa, Mexico, and Flagler Beach, Florida, boat manufacturing facilities, shifting production to high-performing U.S. plants to align with a streamlined product portfolio and evolving market demand.

content.value:
Source | Getty Images

Marine technology company Brunswick Corp. (Mettawa, Ill., U.S.) is consolidating its global fiberglass boat manufacturing footprint in order to reduce fixed costs and unlock greater productivity and efficiency while maintaining the necessary capacity and flexibility for the company’s future growth.

As part of this footprint rationalization, Brunswick will close its Reynosa, Mexico, fiberglass boat manufacturing facility, transitioning production of models currently manufactured in the facility into two of its high-performing U.S.-based manufacturing centers in Vonore, Tennessee, and Merritt Island, Florida. In addition, its Flagler Beach, Florida, production facility will be closed and production of models currently manufactured at that facility will be consolidated into the Edgewater, Florida, operation.

“The decision to transition production out of Reynosa, Mexico — which is primarily dedicated to manufacturing of our small, value fiberglass boats — follows our announcement that we have rationalized our value boat model portfolio, and reflects evolving market dynamics that are impacting industry-wide volumes of value fiberglass products,” explains Brenna Preisser, president of Brunswick Boat Group. “The Reynosa facility and team members have played an important role in our business for many years, and we are committed to supporting their transition. We anticipate the transition will be fully completed by summer 2026.”

Reinforcing its broader integration and expansion effort, Brunswick is investing $5 million in capital improvements across its Tennessee and Florida facilities, further strengthening their capabilities as multi-brand production hubs. This investment underscores Brunswick’s commitment to leveraging its scale to drive operational synergies. These moves will result in the creation of more than 200 U.S. manufacturing jobs over the next several years.

“Brunswick’s Boat Group has sufficient capacity within our manufacturing footprint to absorb volume, support future market rebounds and capture share gains from an aggressive product development roadmap,” Preisser confirms.  “With these and other actions taken to streamline our portfolio and improve productivity, the group will achieve a better structural cost profile and accelerate improved profitability.”

Brunswick is collaborating closely with local government agencies and economic development partners to support a seamless transition. As Boston Whaler consolidates its production operations in Florida, team members from the Flagler Beach facility will be offered opportunities to transfer to the Edgewater location. In addition, the company will soon launch recruitment efforts to fill new positions across production, logistics, engineering and operations management.

title: Hybrid eVTOL orders builds Plana’s FAA certification, U.S. relocation momentum

title_detail.value: Hybrid eVTOL orders builds Plana’s FAA certification, U.S. relocation momentum

summary: Korean AAM company Vonaer will purchase a total of 20 eVTOL aircraft, ramping up Plana’s certification, capital raising and market entry goals.

summary_detail.value: Korean AAM company Vonaer will purchase a total of 20 eVTOL aircraft, ramping up Plana’s certification, capital raising and market entry goals.

content.value:
Hybrid eVTOL aircraft concept for regional air travel. Source | Plana US Inc.

Plana US Inc. has signed a letter of intent to deliver 20 hybrid electric vertical takeoff and landing (eVTOL) aircraft to Vonaer (Seoul), a South Korean-based air mobility service provider. This milestone is part of a larger strategic move as Plana prepares to relocate headquarters to the U.S., and actively purses Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) certification, capital raising and market entry for its eVTOL aircraft platform.

Under the agreement, Plana will supply Vonaer with five certified aircraft by 2033 and an additional 15 by 2040, a value of $664 million. Throughout this contract, Plana has secured pre-orders for a total of 127 aircraft.

Plana’s hybrid eVTOL will use carbon fiber-reinforced polymer (CFRP) composites for the aircraft airframe and prop system. It is equipped with a hybrid power management system that simultaneously operates a certified turbogenerator and a battery system. It can carry up to six passengers and is operated by a single pilot, leveraging instrument flight rule (IFR) and simplified vehicle operation (SVO) technology.

The aircraft has a service range of more than 300 miles on a single refueling, with a maximum speed of over 350 kilometers per hour. Its all-electric propulsion system reduces noise to 1/100th the level of a helicopter, Plana reports, maximizing social acceptance. As a hybrid aircraft, it also has the advantage of being able to use existing infrastructure like helicopter pads.

FAA certification is targeted for end of 2031, with first commercial launch schedued for 2032.

“Our company, which was launched in South Korea, has now completed the establishment of a Delaware corporation in the U.S. and plans to finalize its headquarters relocation within the year to pursue FAA certification, capital raising and market entry,” says Braden J. Kim, founder and CEO of Plana. “Vonaer is a highly influential air mobility service platform provider in Asia. Our aircraft will create a much larger market in a sector currently served by helicopters.”

Plana previously signed an MOU with Vonaer in May 2023. Since then, the companies have jointly analyzed the data realistically required by the market and collaborated on how to properly shape eVTOL travel.

Vonaer is reported to be Korea’s first advanced air mobility (AAM) platform, expanding from helicopter-based services to private jets and eVTOLs. The company is building a hospitality-driven luxury service platform to set the standard for air mobility in Asia and is preparing for expansion into Europe and the U.S.

title: Caracol acquires Hans Weber’s additive manufacturing assets

title_detail.value: Caracol acquires Hans Weber’s additive manufacturing assets

summary: Caracol will acquire Weber’s IP and additive technology with the goal of strengthening the LFAM technological roadmap for European customers and building up its presence in the DACH region.

summary_detail.value: Caracol will acquire Weber’s IP and additive technology with the goal of strengthening the LFAM technological roadmap for European customers and building up its presence in the DACH region.

content.value:
Pictured from left to right: Francesco De Stefano, CEO of Caracol; Ludwig Weber, managing director at Weber; Dr. Markus Weber, managing director at Weber; and Paolo Cassis, COO of Caracol. Source | Caracol

Global large-format additive manufacturing (LFAM) company Caracol (Milano, Italy and Austin, Texas, U.S.) has acquired the IP and robotic machine configuration assets from the additive division of Hans Weber Maschinenfabrik GmbH (Kronach), a German extrusion technology company with more than 100 years of expertise in industrial machinery.

This strategic acquisition serves two main purposes for Caracol: first, to integrate Weber’s additive technology into its product portfolio, creating a highly comprehensive LFAM ecosystem for the market, and addressing a wide range of international customer needs. Second, it reinforces Caracol’s commitment to accelerating the global adoption and industrialization of LFAM technologies across diverse manufacturing sectors, expanding Caracol’s reach in the DACH region

Customers and partners looking to work with Weber’s additive solutions can expect Caracol’s full commitment to continued support and development, gaining access to Caracol’s global field and service network that spans over 55 countries. Backed by Caracol’s holistic approach and deep application expertise, all products will benefit from the same quality service and after-sales support the company is known for, helping businesses scale their production operations with LFAM. Weber will remain a key partner for the development of its extrusion technology and support product development on Caracol’s extended portfolio.

“This agreement combines heritage with innovation, by two companies united by shared values: progressiveness, engineering excellence and a customer-centric mindset,” says Francesco De Stefano, CEO and co-founder of Caracol. “It allows us to strengthen the technological roadmap of two technologies, ensuring each can best fit specific customer’s industrial needs. On the one hand, Caracol’s expertise of the full turnkey technological ecosystem, process and deep vertical application know-how. On the other, Weber’s core expertise on extrusion and machinery manufacturing.”

De Stefano notes that Caracol clients will be able to access Heron platforms with a broader level of customization and configurations to satisfy their specific industrial needs. “This also means additional options when it comes to automation — such as Siemens control or ABB robots,” he says.
